values:
Well, durn it all to heck.

I had written a lovely, long entry about my trip Honduras and was just about to click "update journal" when lighting struck nearby and the power went out for an hour or so. It was a really eloquent entry. Or at least I can say it was.

Hmm... I'll try to sum it up

Honduras was absolutely wonderful. The people were welcoming, the place was beautiful, and I learned an enormous amount, even in that short time, about everything from Miguel's family history to their city's struggle with political corruption to the bogus new president of Honduras to the continuing aftermath of hurricaine Mitch in 98.

I miss it. And not just that surface-ache missing a nice place or that nausea of missing a boyfriend ('cause I feel both of those too). But I really, truly miss Honduras. I connected to it and to the people I met there in a significant way.

I can't wait to go back.

And now, lucky girl that I am, I'm already packing up my backpack for my three-week adventure in Eastern Europe with Chelsea.

Hopefully the power won't go out when I write an update about Europe.

... and very, very, very dry. My state is going to disintigrate into flames sometime soon. 

Hondruas will be very, very, hot... and wet. When I was in Costa Rica I thought I was going to wilt and melt. I don't do well with humidity, being a desert gal.

Me voy para Honduras en, pues... cuatro dias! Unos amigos de Miguel tienen una isla propia en el caribe, y vamos a quedarnos alli por unos dias durante la semana que viene. Tendremos toda la isla tropical para nosotros. Tambien, vamos a visitar las ruinas mayas del Copan. Estoy bien emocionada.

Pandora. Friggin' amazing website: Allows you to enter ANY artist name or song title (well almost any. It didn't know Arvo Part, darn it) from which it creates a station of similar music. Coolest part is you learn about new artists or songs that have some qualities in common with ones you already know and like. And you can save your stations as well as narrow the instructions so that the program plays exactly what you want allllll the time. (Monday update.)
It's funny that I always update on Mondays.

I'm home. It feels different this time. Even though nothing (or very little)physical has changed in my house or in NM since winter break, it feels different this time. It's not summer vacation. I mean, it is in the sense of no work for a while. But there's no schoolyear on the other side of this vacation. I feel at home here, but implicitly less welcome. My parents love having me here and I think they wish I wanted to stay. And everyone else will be glad to see me too. But it's not the same. College students are expected to pop in and out of their hometowns, staying for a weekend or three months depending on the time of year. But college graduates either live at home or they don't. I feel like a wannabe student.

But it's fucking beautiful here.

I am exhausted and spent. In many ways. I don't like graduation. At all. Not because I don't want to leave Pomona, exactly. More because of family and friends and goodbyes and planning and GPAs and awards (or not) and keeping in touch and packing and moving and filling out forms and people you'll never see again.

It's been rough.

But I love my family. I'm so glad my sister and brother-in-law were here. Which is to say, there were good things this weekend even though it sucked overall.

One of the hardest moments of it all came when I was walking through my dorm this afternoon checking to make sure people were moved out by noon. I was checking a suite where four of my best friends lived, and they had all left, so their hall was empty. It's such an unpleasant feeling to be the one who is left when everyone else is gone. Plus, there's so much sadness in emptied dorm rooms. The furniture is haphazardly arranged, everything is dusty, cabinets are open, there's a hairtie or two and a few little forgotten knick knacks. It's eerie. College is strange.

I'm mostly moved into my new apartment. And my mom's still here. We leave Wednesday.

Maria --
[noun]:

An immortal

'How will you be defined in the dictionary?' at QuizGalaxy.com
done...done....done! (With college). Bring on the diploma.

Graduation in two weeks. Two weeks is nothing at all. Half a menstrual cycle. 

Four more on-calls including tonight.

My to-do list is getting shorter.  Except that the ITS poster printer ran out of paper halfway through my thesis poster. Then, I waited while the guy installed new roll of glossy paper and reimbursed my print quota, so I could print again. In the meantime, some other girl started printing her poster ahead of me. When hers was done (two hours after I first arrived at ITS), I tried to print mine again. 1/8 of the way through, it ran out of blue ink and stopped printing. Thanks to the art majors, the ITS guy said.

No blue ink till Tuesday
Presentation tomorrow after long day of apartment hunting and finals-taking.

But, thanks to Tamara, I realized that today is the very last yucky Sunday night full of college homework. I'll drink to that.

I realized today how excited I am to go home and see my dog.

Alumni have congregated on some Clark V steps, red cups of keg-begotten beer in hand. 

Current students stand here and there among them, looking like confused audience members who've been somehow volunteered to go onstage and lend their hands and torsos to a magic show. The graduated men laugh loudly and self-consciously (more loudly and less self-consciously after each beer). But mostly they eyeball any tits and asses that happen to walk by. Tits and asses that, on their way to and from the lacrosse party, happen to be clothed like Catholic schoolgirls. 

A campus safety golf cart hums its way to the scene. Danny, the officer on duty, smiles. "Wanna watch me get cussed out by alumni?" he chuckles as he grits his teeth. 

It's strange to see them. The alumni. They thought too much about what to wear to the party. And it shows.

...everything I have to accomplish before next Wednesday!


<u>Thursday</u>
-- 16 page conservation biology paper (6 pages of which is already written) and accompanying 15-minute powerpoint presentation
-- 5-minute Spanish presentation on a Spanish children's song

<u>Friday</u> 
-- Biochemistry take-home final due

<u>Monday</u>
-- Spanish final exam
-- Thesis presentation

<u>Tuesday</u>
-- 6-8 page Spanish paper and accompanying 5-minute presentation
-- Econ final exam

<u>Wednesday</u>
-- Conservation biology final exam

Pity me!

Nah, it'll all be over so, so soon that it hardly seems worth being stressed out.

<lj-cut text="Where should I live?">

1) Home. 

Pros: I can work at any of a number of fancy restaurants and make good money as well as put in some time at the hospital where I've worked before. I would love to be in NM, and I would be happy to be with my parents.  

Cons: Only one of my good friends will be in NM, and the location will be inconvenient in terms of flying about for med school interviews in the fall.

2) Claremont. 

Pros: I could live with Fay (whom I love) for a reasonable price, work work part time perhaps for dance studio or tutor for Kaplan as well as driving to a Children's Hospital clinic a couple of times a week to volunteer. I would be near Miguel, Josh, Caroline, Sarah Cusser, Molly, and possibly Dave, and I would also be nearer to many places I hope to interview. 

Cons: Claremont for another year. Cost of food and rent.

3) Orange County.  

Pros: Could probably live with a family member for a nominal rent, be a few miles from a dozen or so of my cousins and their kids, and be closer to the Children's Hospital. Also, like Claremont, the location would be relatively convenient in terms of med school visits.  

Cons: My family, although marvelous, is perhaps not the best source of a social life for me, seeing as they're all either married or in middle school. Plus, I'd be coming to Claremont for visits anyway.</lj-cut>

I'm terrible at decision-making. Like really. I always admire those people who look at the possibilities, evaluate the options, and then, magically, these people just CHOOSE. I, on the other hand, look at the possibilities, prevaricate, pontificate, and masticate over them, and then end up with whatever is the default option anyway, or sometimes I manage to hoodwink someone else into making the decision for me.

Rather an unattractive character trait, I must say.

6-7:30 pm -- 2 1/2 butter rum martinis and a bit of baked brie with Fay. 
9-10 pm -- 1 16 oz. Sapporo and sushi at pre-med meeting.
10-11:30 pm -- 3-4 glasses of wine and wonderful munchems at the last Symposium of the year.

Mmmm.  A good night by all accounts. And now to sleep.

Easter dinner with family. <lj-cut text="Good things and bad things.">

Good: Possibility of working at Children's Hospital of Orange County or one of its clinics thanks to cousin Jena who's a marketing bigwig there. 

Bad: Cousin Jay moved to Dallas for work, which means a) as a New Mexican, I am obligated to despise his Texan guts b) I won't get to see him as often because Dallas is way far away from Socal.  

Good: New wee baby cousins are quite adorable. 

Bad: Aunt and Uncle, who are in late 60s seemed OLD, and they've never really seemed old before. Uncle Sonny has gout. Aunt Diane has wrinkly neck and has already packed for their trip to Paris, on which they aren't leaving for another two weeks. Aging family is one of the scariest things. I never had grandparents (all four died before I was born), so I've never really experienced it. But it's definitely starting with my aunts and uncles, and my parents aren't far behind.

Good: Other young cousins are growing up into really awesome pre-teens and teenagers. They seem so old, too, but in a good way. I love them. Especially my 7th-grader cousin, Carey, who I've been close to all her life. She's gonna be such a smart, kick-ass woman. And tall like me. 

Bad: Even though my family is awesome and caring and smart, my anti-racist, anti-heterosexist goals are foreign to their daily lives. Sometimes makes it hard to relate. I should be thankful, I suppose, that this is not true of my immediate family, only of my extended family. I know there are plenty of students and young adults out there who are at odds with parents and siblings, who receive no support even their closest family in terms of their goals. But it's always hard to see the latent racism and heterosexism in some of the people who share my DNA. Reminds me that I'm not nearly so separated from it as I like to think I am. 

Good: Cousin Bryan (father of new, wee adorable baby cousins) was really interested in hearing about my environmental studies and my opinions on species' extinction and global climate change. </lj-cut>

I'm glad I went. Until a year or so ago, I saw them every month or two, but for some reason, I've let a long time lapse between visits lately. The last time I saw this part of my family was my sister's wedding 6 months ago. If I'm still in Socal next year, I need to make the effort to see them more often again. They're so friggin' important to me.

I've put away my rain jacket half a dozen times this spring. And each time, it goes from sunny and warm to rainy and cold within 24 hours. Coincidence? Murphy's law, I say. Which brings me to a second coincidence: my nickname was Murphy in high school. My two best friends in the world still call me Murph. One of my two best friends in the world had her birthday on Tuesday. I fogot to call her. Shitty best-friend behavior. I no longer send gifts to my home friends, so the least I could do would be to call.

I wonder which Pomona people I'll be calling on birthdays four years from now. Never know, I suppose. So much depends on circumstance--where in the world everyone lands after being summarily blown out of the Claremont cannon. My prediction: I'll call Dave, Chelsea, Josh, and maybe Julia on their birthdays for the next several years.

1) Finally, after 4+ years, having the guts to turn in papers in Bookman Old Style rather than Times New Roman. Not because it's bigger. Just because it's prettier. 2) Last minute invitation to Easter dinner with several of my favorite cousins and my favorite Aunt and Uncle. 3) Tom Robbins. 4) Having time (after turning in my thesis on Monday and finishing my last dance performance last weekend) to read Tom Robbins. 5) My parents. 6) No more rain. 7) New LJ look, cuz I'm just that cool. Do you like it? 8) Never having to wear costume again.

Miguel's going to be an RA in Lyon next year. In Dave's old room. And Libby (yay Libby!) and Guga (who were Miguel's sponsors last year in Lyon) are both head sponsors for next year. And the only other Miguel in the school is going to be the third head sponsor.  Oh my.

Saul Williams is going to be here on April 8th at 8 pm for $5. Which is exactly when my last dance performance at Pomona is taking place. How rotten. I have been trying to see him for 4-5 years, but something always gets in my way. I pretty much worship the ground he walks on. You should listen if you get a chance. He also stars in "Slam." Watch it. It's good. Buy the soundtrack. He's on it.

Yar. These are weird days. 

I don't wanna graduate, but I don't not wanna graduate.

New York City is freakin' amazing. I LOVED it. Course, I was living a fantasy life there since we had no obligations and we were staying for free, but damn. I need to live there for a while.

We did so much, I won't even begin to write it out here.

Three aspects I loved the most:

1) People everywhere at every time of night or day, which makes for exciting energy, great people watching, and always something to do. (Unoriginal, I know)

2) The sustainability of it all. Small, locally-owned shops, fabulous public transportation (I am in love with the subway), excellent water treatment (cleanest tapwater in the country), roof gardens, greenspace, the forced realization that there are limited land resources for humans on this planet, contrary to the extended history that suggests the opposite in the Western world, and the ability to maintain contact with people, streets, weather, and air everywhere you go rather than living in the plastic and metal bubble of your car as we all do here in la la land.

3) Finding my history. Seeing as neither California nor New Mexico hold much if any family history for me, seeing the Statue of Liberty imbued me with, not patriotism, but a sense of my past in seeing the place through which four of my great-grandparents and two of my grandparents have come during the last century or so. Also, a second kind of history, a cultural history in the sheer Americana of it all. Having been raised with images, ideas, and standards that emerge from New York City, it was exciting to see those things, icons and otherwise that are embedded in my psyche. Those that struck me most deeply were Radio City Music Hall, Bethesda Fountain, and the generalized bright lights and hubbub of main streets and side streets.

So. I'm going back. I need to see more of the City, the other boroughs, and soak it all up.

I am so very much extremely ready to get me the heck away from here for a wee bit. Yahoo! NYC, here comes  naive, ranch girl Maria!

I hope all y'all who are traveling this week have safe passage.

Love.

In my biochem class today, we had one of the pre-eminent biochemistry experts as a guest, interacting with us as we worked through some material related to his research on iron-sequestering mechanisms of bacteria. This dude's a big deal. Old white guy from Harvard Medical School, over 600 publications, etc, etc, etc. I mean, not exactly famous in the real person world, but nonetheless a big deal. 

Ok, so, I looked pretty put-together today, not gonna lie. My nice herringbone slacks, some of my favorite jewelry, hair up. Don't know why, really, I bothered to look at all nice. Probably cuz I like the way my butt looks in those pants.

Ah, but little did I know that my inability to consume ANYTHING without making a mess had struck again. For, after biochem, after an hour and fifteen minutes of conversing with my group partners, my prof, and this biochemistry god, I returned to my room to discover a centimeter-long smudge of chocolate on my lower lip, begat by a Samoa Girl Scout cookie I had consumed prior to class. Sigh. It's interesting being me...

Which Princess Bride Character are You?
this quiz was made by mysti
yoinked from

Or: I had a wonderful, awful Monday. I have been distinctly unable to complete anything in relation to my thesis (senior exercise) for at least a week or two (or more). Partly thanks to other legitimate things getting in the way (such as my other four classes), and partly thanks to illegitimate things getting in the way (such as photo albums on facebook--curse them). Today was no different.  In fact, this very moment falls into the illegitimate distractions from thesis category. It began raining again, I accomplished nothing, and I felt overwhelmedly distressed by Big Scary Things (graduation--duh).

However, perhaps inexplicably, I find myself in a peaceful, fulfilled headspace tonight. 

Regardless, I find much of what I write in livejournal to be self-aggrandizing.  

Therefore. Next time I will provide something useful to you all.

Well, I'll be! Turns out Miguel's godmother owns a sweet apartment in Greenwich Village and, as she doesn't live there and is currently in Honduras, we suddenly (yesterday) realized that we can go to New York for spring break for $240 round-trip per person and stay for free. Holy macaroni! How freakin' excited am I??? I've never really been to the Big Apple, other than for a few days visiting colleges five years ago. Wowwee. In other news, saw Alvin Ailey in LA Sat. Two of the three pieces were fun but a bit lacking in inspiration. The third, however, was a re-staging of an extremely famous Ailey piece called "Revelations." I absolutely loved it. It was beautiful and amazing, even from the third-to-last row in the entire ENORMOUS theater (four stories up, in the loge). I learned later that they had the music, African-American spirituals, made more modern and pop-y than the original in 1960, which disappoints me and tempers my experience a bit, but I was nevertheless extremely moved by the whole thing. God, if I could spend my life watching dance, how thrilled I would be. Also, in closing, CMC guys (or at least, that's the current conjecture) spread birdseed all over campus over the weekend, broke into Frary, stole deserts, trashed the place, trashed Walker Lounge, and generally caused enormous amounts of work for housekeeping and dining services without impacting the students really at all. What crap. So far, Pomona has not retaliated in kind. I sincerely hope it remains that way.

So, in my Scripps 44-level Spanish class today, we had a discussion about racism, particularly inequalities in education, and affirmative action. There are (ahem) a few individuals in that class with whom I very much disagree on these topics. But damn. It's hard enough to form coherent sentences in English regarding something about which I have such strong emotions (maybe I should have taken some debate lessons from <lj user="liylak">). But in another language, in which I am only passably fluent... oy. Frustrating.


Also, I'm well aware my posts have been far from riveting lately, but damn y'all, leave me some comments, because I'm beginning to feel unloved (*sniff)!

Your Candy Heart Says "Hug Me"
A total sweetheart, you always have a lot of love to give out. Your heart is open to where ever love takes you! Your ideal Valentine's Day date: a surprise romantic evening that you've planned out Your flirting style: lots of listening and talking What turns you off: fighting and conflict Why you're hot: you're fearless about falling in love
What Does Your Candy Heart Say?

When I received an email today from Andy and Brian about their visit to Claremont this weekend and their gig on Friday night, I felt so, so happy to be included in the list of 20-ish friends at the 5Cs they sent it to.

<lj-cut text="Lasts">
Last dream: That I got drunk off of drugged punch at a house party and was supposed to meet my dad the next morning, but instead I passed out at the house and woke up in the morning without my sweater or my shoes, and as a result, somehow, I ended up with a parole officer (ps. some people really hate hearing other people's dreams. I, on the other hand, love dreams and hearing others' dreams.)

Last car ride: Back from renting a movie last night.

Last kiss: Before going to sleep.

Last good cry: Hmmm...a week or so ago

Last Missing Library Book: Thesis books. ALL my thesis books. Clearly. Otherwise, I'd be working on thesis, wouldn't I?

Last movie seen: Tried to watch Monty Python and the Holy Grail last night, but my computer was screwy. So, in fact, the last movie I saw was The Perfect Score, which sucked except that Scarlett Johansen (sp?) is hot in it.

Last Book Read: Mary Poppins. And Biochemistry.

Last curse word uttered: Shit.

Last beverage drank: Emergen-C

Last food consumed: 21 Choices! Hurrah! (Animal cookie parade with Twix mixed in)

Last really wonderful moment: Seeing Kamau at the game last night.

Last phone call: Parents

Last TV show watched: Something over break...Don't remember what. Trash, undoubtedly. Probably on HGTV.

Last Item Bought: 21 Choices.

Last time showered: No comment.

Last shoes worn: Flip-flops. Duh.

Last annoyance: Monty Python not playing on my computer.

Last soda drunk: Don't drink soda.

Last trip to the bathroom: Half hour ago.

Last time you yelled at someone: Friday night.

Last weird encounter: Every encounter with my thesis advisor.

Last Store Shopped at: Um?

Last Shirt Worn: Pomona College Welcome Team Ask Me!

Last class attended: Ballet Friday.

Last time dancing: Salsa a couple of weeks ago at Rio Grande. </lj-cut>

Man. I overshot heaven. Way to be.
Sing along about the evils of Exxon Mobil. What could be better on a Friday afternoon?

1. I am so unabashedly, unbelievably glad I dropped biochem on the drop deadline last semester and am now taking it at HMC. Even though Liz made the class almost-bearable last semester, the prof, assignments, and lack of lab are all absolutely superior at Mudd. It's one of my favorite classes ever. Miguel makes fun of me, says, maybe because you fit in better at Mudd. I choose to ignore him when he says that

2. I can't bear to watch the State of the Union. The sight of that man gives me the chills. As does his voice. Come to think of it, pretty much anything that bears any trace of him at all makes me ill.

3. Thesis. Bah.

4. I guess there isn't really a 4. Short list, then...

Gray, gloomy Wednesday afternoon spent in the library working on thesis. 

Yep. Must be that time of year.

What sex is your brain? Interesting test from the BBC website. I scored smack-dab in the middle. I'm not sure how I feel about this sort of thing from a gender studies standpoint, but there is biological basis to some of it, as far as I understand it.
He wrote this and an entire book called Daddy Needs a Drink. I was there for the "pussy" phase, and damn, it was hilarious.

So my last RA training just ended. THANK GOD. 

The end

Leaving New Mexico invariably causes a wrenching, tangled sadness inside me. At 5:45 yesterday morning, I said goodbye to my cat, my dog, my parents, and my house, got in the car and drove away crying. And it's not like it's the first time I've left. Nor was it a particularly eventful or spectacular break. 

On my way out of town, in pitch-black, before-dawn silence, I picked up an acquaintance-y friend from high school, who accompanied me on the drive here because he's working on some computer animation project in Pasadena for a couple of weeks. We had an smooth drive and many hours of easy conversation, which was a pleasant surprise, considering that the longest we'd ever spent alone together before yesterday was probably half an hour. 

It's utterly disconcerting to wake up at home and to drive down Indian Hill at sunset that same day. I'll be happy to see people when they start arriving this weekend. But man, I have such mixed feelings about being here and about starting my last semester.

Perhaps the strangest thing of all is that home may not quite be home next time I go back because my parents, after living in the same house for 29 years, are considering moving a little ways out of town, into this beautiful, very small house in the mountains with unbelievable views and direct access to hiking trails and wood-burning stoves. It's an awesome place, definitely the kind of home in which I see myself living as an adult, but it's extremely strange to think of my family being in any other house.

Fuck it. I don't want to grow up.
Four more days in Santa Fe. Not enough. And what a vacation it's been. Sometime I'll have to tell you all about it.

Went to one of the few good hang-out bars in town with Rachel last night. Was a walk through all the stages of my life because there were friends there I've known since kindergarten, some girls I danced with for years, people I went to high school with, and this really awesome musicsian playing named Alex Mariel who's been rockin Santa Fe for a few years now. Santa Fe's crazy like that. Plus, got invited to sit with a Persian optomitrist and a Moroccan vagabond who are recent transplants to Santa Fe. Had some pretty amazing conversations. When one of my high school friends walked by the table, he began speaking Arabic with the Moroccan. Had no idea he spoke Arabic. Drank Bailey's all the while. Mmm.

I don't know how I feel about New Years' Resolutions. Seems to me they're just another way to make oneself feel guilty, especially when they're big, self-motivating type things. I don't usually make them. But maybe I should.

Ah man. Coming home means awkward alumni party at my high school, at which my class ('02) is actually the most well-represented, and at which more than one member of the class of '92 sizes me up, talks to me, and/or asks me out.  

Coming home means hanging out at friends' houses with all my old classmates (who have all stayed unbelievably close to one another, which makes it even weirder, since I haven't stayed close to them) and feeling, utterly bizarrly, like it could be any given high school hang out evening.  

Coming home means coffee with my high school boyfriend, who is perhaps the least likely person you could possibly imagine for me, and yet, we still have a real and friendly connection.

A low-key Christmas in many ways. My sister is with my brother-in-law and his family in Bumblefuck, Wisconsin, and their absence is always a sore spot for the holidays. (Side note: is it weird that I'm better friends with my brother-in-law than with my sister?) We went by a convalescence home at lunchtime to visit an old family friend who's in her 90's and has just in the last few months lost a lot of her health. We totally weren't prepared for what we found, though. She's mostly deaf and didn't recognize us, nor did she ever really figure out that we were there to see her. She kept asking (sort of unintelligibly) whether she should go get so-and-so, as if we were there to visit someone else and she needed to go find them. That was really hard for all of us. We left after a few minutes because there was nowhere to sit (she was in her wheelchair simply stationed in the hallway), and we had no way to engage her. I'm glad we went. I'm sure she appreciated a smiling face on Christmas regardless, but man, aging is scary. Plus, it made me just sort of angry that her family wasn't there with her on Christmas. They live out of state. But, since I don't know all the circumstances, I relaly can't judge. Nonetheless, there is a lot to be thankful for, and I've had a good day with my parents--good food, a few good gifts, and beautiful weather.

Another gorgeous day, another hike with my mom. Less wind.

We tried to go to the Animal Shelter to adopt a dog (our 14-year-old lab died last spring and we've been thinking about finding a new dog for a few monthes now) but our efforts were thwarted because the Animal Shelter was closed. Bollocks. 

Looking forward to all the traditional Santa Fe Christmas Eve stuff tonight.

Warmest Christmas EVER. Good ol' global warming, que no?

I like how I lose track of email and otehr computer distractions when I'm at home. At school, I feel this ugly need to check my email every ten minutes and check for friends' LJ updats. But at home, I get distracted instead by crossword puzzles and books I've been meaning to read.

Miguel was here. Was fabulous. Three of my four best friends in the world got to meet him. I wonder if it was weird for them seeing me with someone else. Had a grand time showing him around Santa Fe, Taos, etc, etc. I only wish he could've stayed longer. He flew back to Honduras on a redeye this morning and arrived safely, but without his enormous duffle bag that contained ALL his clothes and Christmas gifts. The airline, TACA, said he'll get it in 6-12 days. Rotten.

Just went for a hike with my mom out along the railroad that leads from Santa Fe to the tiny town of Lamy. It's a beautiful, clear, relatively warm day, and it was lovely to walk a long way in view of all the mountains. The way back was a trek against the winds, which have been quite blustery these days. Glad to be in my warm house.

Aside from depression, eating disorders, and some other smaller weirdnesses, it's good to see my friends and my parents.

Christmas party tonight at my friend Emma's house. Time to dress up and see old friends. I love it.

I'm definitely close now. Can definitely taste it. I'm so eager to go home. My parents, after much agony, decided to buy an artificial tree for the first time ever this year. They took it out of the box on Saturday, set it up, adjusted the branches, and promptly took it down on Sunday because it had no "life forces."  How Santa Fe of them. So they returned it, and we'll have a real tree after all.

And only one hour-long test and an 8-page paper in between.
